5. Santa Maria Sequence I fossilization aspects 250 

As previously described by Holz and Schultz (1998), the main fossilization mineralogy of the 251 

Santa Maria Sequence is calcite and hematite. In SMS1the bone condition varies from perfectly 252 

preserved (fig. 6A; 6B) to totally destroyed material. A peculiarity of these bones is the destruction for 253 

displacive calcite growth. Despite the tendency of compactational crush, the bones filled with calcite 254 

expand (Fig. 6C; 6D). There is commonly a calcite/hematite incrustation, even in well preserved 255 



11 

 

bones, which shows great carbonate availability in groundwater. Microscopically, as mentioned 256 

before, calcite in the Santa Maria Supersequence fossils can take two different habits: megacrystalline 257 

or microcrystalline. Hematite is commonly spread in Haversian channels near to the bone apatite, or as 258 

stains inside calcite aggregates. On the top of this sequence, indicated in figure 2 as Santacruzodon 259 

AZ, chalcedony and quartz appear as authigenic minerals in fossilization (Reichel et al. 2005) (Fig. 260 

6E; F). Bones can also be cracked, and these fractures are filled with druzy or spatic calcite and 261 

hematite. Both appear as stains associated in general with dissolution features on calcite. Cracked 262 

osteons are common in the fossils. Sometimes, inside the bone marrow cavity, besides calcite and 263 

hematite there is detritic quartz and feldspar, carried inside from the surrounding sediment by the 264 

groundwater flow.  265 

6. Santa Maria Sequence II fossilization aspects 266 

6.1 Base 267 

The fossilization process of the base of this sequence is very similar to that of the SMS I, but 268 

without the presence of authigenic silicatic minerals. Here the expansive destruction of the bone is less 269 

common than in the Sequence I.    270 

6.2 Top 271 

The top of the SMS II is mainly preserved by calcite, with low percentage of hematite in small 272 

bones (Table 1). Large bones bear calcite and hematite in equal proportions, and all bones bear a thin 273 

incrusted hematite coat. Once more, hematite occurs near the bone apatite (Fig. 6G; 6H). Radial cracks 274 

on osteons are a common feature. The bones are hardly deformed, except for compactational crush 275 

and, in general, they are well preserved (Fig. 7A). Calcite appears only as megacrystals, filling totally 276 

the Havers channels and bone marrow. The presence of detritic minerals as quartz and feldspar inside 277 

the bone is also reported, and it is more common than in other sequences (Fig. 7B). 278 

7. Discussion 279 

7.1 Fossildiagenesis  280 



12 

 

The results presented here corroborate those of Holz and Barberena (1994) and Holz and 281 

Schultz (1998), who proposed that the fossils from the SMS I were preserved in the phreatic level and 282 

not thru mesodiagenetic processes. For the top of  the SMS II, there are no mineral evidences that 283 

indicate mesodiagenetic processes, as proposed by Zerfass et al. (2000). The phreatic level variations 284 

generate and mix the authigenic minerals formed during the different stages and produce a complex 285 

diagenetic sequence. All bones of the SMS I display hematite as the first precipitated mineral, 286 

followed by calcite, regardless its preservational state. After that, the diagenetic sequence is not clear.  287 

There is a clear difference between calcite features in well and poorly preserved bones. In well 288 

preserved bones, calcite crystals are bigger and occupy all the space in the bone cavities with only one 289 

crystal. In poorly preserved bones, calcite appears as micro sparry crystals. All analyzed samples 290 

showed the same pattern (Fig. 7C). Some of the mineral features present on fossil bone are very 291 

similar to those described for groundwater calcretes, like micro sparry calcite and alternated 292 

precipitation of calcite and hematite. This feature (Fig. 7D) shows clearly that the bone stayed in 293 

groundwater oscillation zone, as described by Moore (1989).  294 

Cracked osteons are a common feature in both sequences (Fig. 8A). This feature is interpreted 295 

as desiccation cracks, caused by the loss of water from bone matrix to atmosphere in arid climates 296 

(Pfretzschner, 2011). It also indicates that some bones were exposed before its final burial for some 297 

time.  298 

The presence of silica minerals in carbonatic concretions is indicative of abnormal water 299 

availability, i.e., water was available for enough time to precipitate chalcedony (Landmesser, 1988). 300 

Only fossils of the Santacruzodon AZ showed this feature, which means that these fossils suffered 301 

fossildiagenesis in wetter conditions, distinguishing them from those originated from the other 302 

assemblage zones.  303 

There is no evidence of a reducing early phase of diagenesis, although these evidences could 304 

have been destroyed by a later oxidizing phase. The mineralogy found in these fossils, from both 305 



13 

 

sequences, indicates that they are precipitated in an environment with pH greater than 8. The absence 306 

of pyrite remains or its pseudomorphosis by hematite indicates that Eh was above 0. 307 

Based on the geochemical information discussed above, a fossildiagenetic model is proposed 308 

for the Santa Maria Supersequence. Due to the similarity of fossildiagenetic process and fossiliferous 309 

rocks this Supersequence is divided into: SMS I/SMS II (base) and SMS II (top). 310 

In the first model, the fossiliferous rock is a mudstone that belongs to a floodplain deposit. 311 

These rocks are associated with calcretes, some of them formed in groundwater oscillation zone. The 312 

association of calcretes with fossils in the Santa Maria Supersequence was already reported by Holz 313 

and Schultz (1998) and Da Rosa et al. (2004). Before the burial (Fig. 9A), bones could be exposed for 314 

a long period, and due to the arid conditions, developed cracks (Fig. 9B). After the bone final burial, 315 

because of the alkaline conditions inside the bone, it began to accumulate hematite that is commonly 316 

remobilized in groundwater situations (Fig. 9C). As a result of semi-arid climate, the deposition of 317 

calcite is common inside the soil, but it is more concentrated in the groundwater oscillation zone. So 318 

the calcite deposition in soil profile or inside phreatic zone deposited the spatic crystals that do not 319 

expand the bone (Fig. 9D). In the zone of phreatic level oscillation the precipitation rate and the 320 

number of seed crystals is higher than in the other zones, due constant remobilization. Because of this, 321 

a great quantity of calcite small crystals are formed together and alternated with hematite, enough to 322 

expand the bone. The precipitation do not break the compact bone structure, it expands from an 323 

already weakened bone by the cracks made before the final burial (Fig. 8B, 9E ). In the SMS I/SMS II 324 

(base) the calcrete indicates that the groundwater oscillation zone was not deep, so it was possible to 325 

expand the bone despite the sediment column weight. Bones could enter and exit many times the 326 

oscillation zone, thus generating the great variability of preservational stages (Fig. 10). 327 

The SMS II top is a deltaic system formed by a fine sandstone deposit that contains fossil 328 

bones. Deltaic systems are unlikely environments to calcrete development and fossil preservation due 329 

to constant erosion and remobilization of sediments. Even though, the sandstone porosity contributes 330 

to groundwater percolation, essential to preserve bones. Before the burial, bones were commonly 331 



14 

 

exposed for a long time, and as a result of the semi-arid conditions, developed cracks. The first 332 

mineral to precipitate is hematite. Unlike the conditions, here calcrete would not be normally formed, 333 

the calcite precipitation is not so intense on groundwater oscillation zone, and calcite precipitates as 334 

big crystals that do not expand the bones. The groundwater that flow inside the sediment can transport 335 

silt-size quartz grains from the surrounding rock to inside the bone, before it is filled with calcite.  336 

The abundance of calcite inside the sediment lowers from the SMS I to the SMS II. To form 337 

calcretes is necessary a stable plain, without a constant sedimentation for the soil development and 338 

preservation. In the Santa Maria Supersequence the humidity and sedimentary influx increases from 339 

the Sequences I to II, and the floodplain deposits disappear on the top of the Sequence II. The period 340 

between two depositional episodes gradually diminished, as well as the period for calcrete formation, 341 

decreasing the possibility of bone expansion. 342 

7.2 Bone apatite 343 

Biologic apatite is naturally impure and contains variable quantities of carbonate (Legeros and 344 

Legeros, 1984). Due to the abundance of CO3
2-

 in groundwater, the entrance of carbonate in 345 

hidroxylapatite is common during the fossilization process, as well as the OH
-
-F

-
substitution 346 

(Piepenbrink, 1989; Hedges, 2002; Piga et al., 2011). The presence of F in apatite has a stabilizing 347 

effect that increases the bone preservation. Biologic hidroxylapatite is not stable under normal 348 

sedimentary conditions. XRDA data presented here shows two apatite types, carbonate fluorapatite 349 

and fluorapatite, despite the growing quantity of CO3 inside apatite.  350 

The heterogeneity of apatite after fossilization in well preserved bones is normally caused by 351 

differential modification from bone core to the edges. This could be due to the greater porosity of bone 352 

marrow compared with the remainder of the bone. The empty space inside the bone is a preferential 353 

conduct to solutions that percolates the bone. When a solution interacts with the apatite bone 354 

substitutions of ions can occur inside apatite (diadochy), promoting modifications in the crystalline 355 

structure. This heterogeneity tends to disappear with the continuous alteration of the bone, first leading 356 

to a duality between fluorapatite and calcite, followed by a completely bone apatite replacement. 357 



15 

 

The bone marrow is more susceptible to interactions with groundwater; consequently ion 358 

exchanges and substitutions are maximized in this place. In the present contribution it was possible to 359 

verify that the increase of carbonate substitutions in the inner of the bone modifies the apatite cell 360 

parameters. The crystallochemical changes were studied by XRDA and FTIR. 361 

8. Conclusions 362 

The petrological and geochemical study of the fossildiagenesis in the Santa Maria 363 

Supersequence permitted to conclude that: 364 

1. The fossilization mineralogy of the SMS I and SMS II, (former Santa Maria and Caturrita Fms.) is 365 

predominantly calcite and hematite, with the eventual presence of chalcedony in the SMS I, in 366 

agreement with the works of Holz and Barberena (1994), Holz and Schultz (1998) and Reichel, 367 

Schultz and Pereira (2005). Also, there is no evidence of mesodiagenetic processes, as previously 368 

proposed by some authors. In both processes occur osteon cracks, indicating that bones were exposed 369 

before the final burial. 370 

2. The fossildiagenesis of the SMS I and SMS II (base) is related to calcrete formation. Similar 371 

petrographic features of calcretes and fossils, as sparry calcite and alternated precipitation of calcite 372 

and hematite, indicate a phreatic origin of these cements. Bone swelling is caused by displacive 373 

growth of calcite in groundwater oscillation zone. It occurred through cracks or discontinuities in bone 374 

structure (e.g. growth lines), which are resulting features of  the bone expositionprior to the burial. The 375 

variability of preservation modes are a result of the oscillation of the groundwater depth, since there is 376 

distinct preservation stages in the same bone.        377 

3. XRDA and FTIR analyses showed that hydroxylapatite changed with the fossildiagenetic process, 378 

turning into carbonate fluorapatite or fluorapatite. Carbonate substitutions occur to stabilize apatite 379 

inside the sedimentary circle, since the uptake of F
-
 ions by apatite reduces the apatite solubility, 380 

contributing to the bone preservation. The changes of a axis parameter from a recent to a fossilized 381 

bone indicate that the structural changes caused by ionic exchanges between bone apatite and the 382 

groundwater dissolved ions. 383 



16 

 

4. Petrography data, FTIR and XRDA crystalline refinement showed that the modifications of apatite 384 

structure occurred first in the bone marrow, being this part always the most altered in the bones. This 385 

occurs because the hollow portion of the bone works as a preferential percolation water channel during 386 

the diagenesis that promotes the increase of ion exchanges in this site. 387
